Now, i am no fan of 50 cent, believe me - but Get Rich actually shows he has, however little, some talent. If you consider The Massacre, this will seem like a classic.

The album starts with a coin hitting the floor, and a gun being loaded (Intro), which pretty much somes up Fiddys forte. Guns and cash. timing at just under a minute is the follow up (What Up Gangsta), with an introduction to his life, pumped by a grimey beak, and half assed rhymes, with an annoying chorus... a very skippable track. (Patiently Waiting) gives some hope, with a better beat, backed up by Eminems vocals about halfway through the song. If you thought 50 had a great lyrically talent up to now, he seems to be outshined by his mentor. Yet another repetitive chorus, but overall a good track...

A skit to the next track, with bullets being fired, enters (Many Men), which 50 explains how he is headhunted by everyone. he drops lines like 'Im the underground king/ Who aint been Crowned'

and 'Like ali in his prime' - which is a bit to pretantious/obnoxious for me. The single that got overplayed on te radio (In Da Club) chimes next. if you haven't heard this, you must be a tourist from neptune. 50 adds some humor to this catchy track, with some adrenaline pumped lyrics, but still doesnt capture the ears of mine fully. (High All The Time) explains itself - the drug track that can be found all over the G-Unit albums. But this subject has grown old, and the beat doesnt help. Pass.

A beat composed of gunshots, and lyrics remenicent of the gangsta-ish lyrics of the 90's actually works for 'half a dollar' on (Heat), probably the most replayable track on GRODT... with a mildly funny skit at the beggining, and some ad libbing at the end - which don't add, but tie up the seventh track on this LP. (If I Cant) posesses a diffrent kind of rhythm, sounding more like it could be on The Massacre. im not saying its a bad song, just average and samey, with a chorus: 'if i cant - do it homey - it cant be done - now ima let the champagne bottle pop - ima take ya to the top - fo sho ima make ya hot baby' and more 'g unit mentions' that would make you think the CD was skipping at sometimes...

(Blood Hound) features an appearance from G Unit soldier- YoungBuck, whose album i prefer to this one. He adds nothing to this song though, with poor rhyming and lack in skill. And whats with he 'Woof' in the backround? Shut that sh*t up! Check the chorus for a sum up to fiftys lifestyle. with the hit and miss tracklist, we close into the last part of the album, with a diss to Ja Rule (Back Down). But this is no Ether, and you've probably read the same thing in a magazine article. It ends with someone, posing as a homosexual boyfriend of Ja trying to be funny, and failing after the first listen. The next track has one of the best beats on the CD, but suprisingly, was not by Em or Dre. i think it was kuniva of D12, but cant remember right now anyway. anyways, (P.I.M.P) is 50 showing that he does not need the stereotypical Perm or Cadillac to be a pimp. while this song does offer some enjoyment, and an average video, it does what In Da Club does, and wears out,to noones fault but the radio and MTV.

From what i have heard, Tony Yayos (G unit ex-incarcerated member) album does not do anything for him, so i won't even bother listening to it, but he features on the next track (Like My Style) if only for a little amount of time - carlessly not showing the rap prowess he could have. (Poor Lil Rich) is one of the dullest tracks on the album, which is a shame as the last three tracks are actually quite good.

They are (21 Questions) which has an appearance from the master of hooks - Nate Dogg. the beat on the track does sound similar to P.I.M.P but then again, that isn't a bad thing. And finnaly, 50 cent stirs away from the gangbanging-gunslinging attitude splattered on all the other tracks to make a mellowish track which is one of my faveroutes on the album, giving relief from the grime you just expiereinced of the last however many minutes.  To finish up the G-unit features, is Lloyd Banks, and a return from slim shady for (Dont Push Me), an even darker track than most of the rest, and you can hear Lloyd in the backround of the line - 'So Dont Push Me' in the chorus. Now this is the best verse from the G-Unit lot, proving Banks has something to show for himself, outshining his homie, But then Eminem finishes off with an outstanding verse proving he still has it, apart from his 'Oh/No/Yo/Ho' line which ruins it a bit. Still, this song is great, and worth the listen. The album ends with (Gotta Make It To Heaven) - another boring track which should have been left out of the album.

In short - only about 7 tracks desereved to be put on this album, an average effort from what would become the most Ovverated rapper ever. 50's good, but nothing special. Peace

This is the ESSENTIAL Michael Jackson collection you're looking for! What's so great about it is that the occasional as well as die-hard fan will appreciate this collection for different reasons.

Occasional fan view:
Great selections of early (Motown) tracks are on here. The Jackson 5 hits like "ABC" and "I Want You Back" are featured and tracks like "Ben" and "Rockin' Robin'" that were some of Michael's first solo appearances are highlights. This compilation also features a few hits from the Jacksons career at Epic Records, including the huge hit "Shake Your Body (Down to the Ground)." The centerpiece of the entire collection is the inclusion of tracks from OFF THE WALL, THRILLER and BAD. Every hit from all three albums are featured here and then some! These hits alone could have made up their own compilation! There is also a very nice selection of tracks from DANGEROUS; including the #1 hit "Remember the Time." The classic "You Are Not Alone" from HISTORY: PAST, PRESENT AND FUTURE BOOK 1 is here as well as Michael's most recent hit "You Rock My World." Wow, 38 great songs all in one package. This is the best collection of Michael's hits anywhere!

Die Hard fan view:
Outside of the unreleased tracks, overall this package is much better than the 5 Disc Box set ULTIMATE COLLECTION. That collection contains all LP versions of tracks, unless noted. That was unfortunate for fans looking for the edits of "Wanna Be Startin' Somethin'" and "Rock With You" which have yet to see the light of day on CD...until the ESSENTIAL collection! Just having both of these rare edits makes this package very special to Michael's fans. On the down side, the tracks from BAD are all LP versions, and the "Spoken Intro" to "I Just Can't Stop Loving You" is STILL missing. (FYI: The only CD I have found the "Spoken Intro" version on is the Japanese BAD PICTURE DISC CD.) The selections from DANGEROUS are nice, but are only LP versions or remix edits, which can be found on multiple CD singles. I was unimpressed with the track selection representing HISTORY: PAST, PRESENT AND FUTURE BOOK 1. The only track that appears from that release is "You Are Not Alone." Where in the world is "Scream"? It is not on here or the ULTIMATE COLLECTION. There has to be a "Michael Only" version in the archives (no offense to Janet...much love to her!) I'm guessing Sony still wants to sell HISTORY: PAST, PRESENT AND FUTURE BOOK 1 so they leave off from this and every other collection one of Michael's biggest hits. As suspected, only "You Rock My World" represents INVINCIBLE. Perhaps there would have been more hits if more tracks were released from one of Michael's finest work. However, THE ESSENTIAL MICHAEL JACKSON is still a must have for every fan!

Here we have yet another attempt at collecting Michael Jacksons greatest hits - the FOURTH in a mere 10 years! Ironically, none of them succeeds. Personally, I don't care too much for the Jackson 5 period - but if they wanted to include the songs, at least they could do it properly and include ALL the hits. Ditto for the Jacksons period - arguedly Blame It On The Boogie, Shake Your Body (Down To The Ground) and Can You Feel It was their best three tracks, but a more comprehensible coverage would have been nice. They should have made 1 full disc only of Jackson 5 and Jacksons material.

From this point, it gets better. All 4 singles from Off The Wall is included - Working Day And Night would have been a nice add-on, but it wasn't a single, so that can be excused. All SEVEN singles from the Thriller album is here - good job, that's how it should be in a real 'essential' compilation. EIGHT of nine singles from the Bad album is included - the omission of Liberian Girl can be excused from the fact that it was an UK only single - it was a nice song, though, could've made it onto here. SEVEN cuts from Dangerous is also a nice representation -  they left off two single tracks (Gone Too Soon and Give Into Me, both UK only singles) and included instead title track, which I applaude, since I think it's one of the best dance tracks he's done.

And this is where it goes completely wrong. The US release has only 1 (ONE?) single from HIStory, the European version has three, which is better, but not good enough. FIVE songs were released from this album as singles - Scream, They Don't Care About Us, Stranger In Moscow, Earth Song (UK only) and You Are Not Alone. All are excellent songs. All should have been included. Blood On The Dance Floor had 3 single cuts (title track, Ghosts and HIStory remix and also Is It Scary which was out on promo singles) - none of them are included here. From Invincible, You Rock My World is included, while Cry isn't - which was by far the better of the two tracks. Also, Butterflies was a US hit, but isn't included here - I never liked the song, but it still should be here. Single from latest release #1's, Another Chance, isn't included as well.

The near complete omission of material from 1995 and later is rediculous, and makes this compilation totally incomplete. They should have made it a 3CD compilation instead: Disc 1 - Jackson 5 + Jacksons + Off The Wall. Disc 2 - Thriller + Bad. Disc 3 - Dangerous + HIStory + Blood On The Dance Floor + Invincible. Then we would be talking.

But don't forget: This music is some of the best that was produced during the 80'es and 90'es.

Moen seems to have been around forever as a Christian song writer and worship leader. Perhaps that's why he doesn't seem to get a lot of respect...his name doesn't come to mind immediately when one thinks of today's top worship songwriters.

But he doesn't do his thing for respect, of course. And he's amazingly consistent.

Thank You Lord is the follow-up to I Will Sing, a brilliant live-in-concert worship recording that isn't easy to follow up. But Moen manages to pull it off with his usual smooth vocals and very strong pop arrangements. True, the guy goes to the well too often with dramatic change-of-key climaxes to his songs...that tends to dilute their power a bit...but the songs are so well crafted you can't help but come to a worshipful place.

For me, the standouts are the title track (it's brought me near tears a few times) and This Is Your House. Both should find a place in any church willing to look beyond the Matt Redmans and Chris Tomlins of this world.

Dr Dre is delighted, fans are joyous, and Curtis Jackson`s ego is beginning to expand.  But as 50cent continues to captivate universal Hip-Hop audiences, I am finding it rather difficult to control my frustration!  It is always cheering when a real raconteur stampedes the stage, but once again, I am left wondering what is it exactly that has evoked the mournful revolution in Rap.  The "Next 2Pac", has just began performing his implement, releasing a platinum album and to create the biggest buzz in the world of Hip-Hop.  But unfortunately, the enigmatic withdrawal of intelligent lyrics on POOR LIL RICH is just a brief exemplification of every other track on the album.  The litany of references to violence becomes tedious, (WHAT UP GANGSTER), (IF I CANT), (BLOOD HOUND), and (DONT PUSH ME).  In those final hours of uncertainty, (WISH DEATH), once again fails to duplicate the prophetic style of so many others in the past.  As his devouring passion for weaponry becomes the leitmotif in this LP, the obsession has led Rap music into the most self-destructive calamity ever known!  And those dispatched to the world of meaningful lyrics outpost will not enjoy the radio-friendly hits (IN DA CLUB) and (P.I.M.P.).  If only 50Cent wrote his lyrics as ambitiously as he strives to appear on television adverts!  Instead of a more pragmatic approach to solve his problems, it seems 50cent believes a combatitave one is the answer, (BACK DOWN).  Buy this album if you are entertained by incessant bragging and meaningless lyrics, but otherwise do you utmost best to avoid!  Sometimes it makes you believe Rap music can not get any worse than this, (until you hear Will Smith)!

I never gave this band any thought until I saw them cover Metallica's "Master of Puppets" for 2003's MTV Icon. And though they didn't play the whole song, they did play the solo and the fact that they were able to pull that off got the attention of me.  When some kid I knew was giving away CD's he didn't listen to anymore, along with two other CD's, I picked this one just to see what the boys were made of. Well, I was a bit disappointed.  It seems that though these guys grew up listening to bands like Judas Priest and Iron Maiden (as mentioned in the song "Fat Lip") and seem to be decently talented players, they are either only capable of writing pop-punk music or they were just focusing on what pleases the masses when making this record.

I was hoping to see what else the lead guitarist could do, but I found out there were hardly any solos on here, and the ones that were there weren't very interesting.

There is a tribute to 80's metal called "Pain for Pleasure", and some rap-rock ("Fat Lip") but other than that everything pretty much sounds the same.

Now, I haven't heard anything else they've done, and I'm not going to judge them on just one album, if you like simple pop-punk then you'll like this album, if not you won't. That is all.

I have listened to all of Steve Gaines's cds, 1) One in the Sun, 2) Okie, 3)I Know a Little. I have actually
thrown duplicate copies of the latter two cds into the trash simply because I thought the music was so
horrendous. People fell in love with Steve Gaines because he played with a great band for a year and a half.
Steve Gaines became a household name because he first played with Allen Collins, Gary Rossington, the band and
because he wrote some with Ronnie Van Zant. Steve was a good guitar player and he brought a lot to Skynyrd. Steve
expanded the range of Skynyrd for a short time. But then too so did Ed King whom Gaines replaced on guitar.
Skynyrd was always better with three guitars. The three guitar lineup fleshed Lynyrd Skynyrd into a rock
and roll contender. Sure, Allen Collins and Gary Rossington were great on guitar but something was still lacking.
The third guitarist fleshed out the band and completed and complemented it.

Of the three Steve Gaines cds that were released commercially, all I can say of them is that they clearly show
a musician who was making some very non professional or novice music. To my ears the music is mostly quite bad.
And of the choices for songs I can only ask where was this guy was coming from?

Steve Gaines became an instant LEGEND because he DIED after a short tenure with Lynyrd Skynyrd. In that short
period the man thrilled us by being at his peronal BEST. He wrote and sang "Ain't No Good Life." LEGEND, the
Skynyrd album of 1987 introduced us to Steve's song "One in the Sun", which is another decent Skynyrd song. Steve
also wrote "I Know A Little", and he was involved somehow in "You Got That Right" and "I Never Dreamed." This
was Steve Gaines at the HEIGHT of his professional career.

Now forget about the short Skynyrd tenure and you have a man playing what, The Holiday Inn or some bar. Ronnie
and Skynyrd RESCUED Steve Gaines from complete OBSCURITY. And let me say that Steve Gaines served Ronnie well
in a time when he had writer's block. Ronnie was somewhat exhausted musically when Steve joined the band. Ronnie
was the heart and soul of the band. Ronnie was the leader. Steve brought some personal MATURITY to the band. Steve
helped with some vocals and gave Ronnie the ONLY REST he ever got on vocals.

However, all three of Steve's albums/collections serve little more than to remind us of what Lynyrd Skynyrd did
for Steve Gaines. Steve may never have made it without Skynyrd. From what I hear of Steve's music I feel the man
probably would never have made it. Luckily though Skynyrd FOUND Steve via his sister Cassie Gaines. Cassie is the
one who told Skynyrd about her guitar playing brother.

Rest in Peace Steve and Cassie, and all the lost Skynyrd members.

Amy Grant is a raw talent.  Her career has spanned nearly 4 decades and during that time she has managed to find success in the Christian, Pop, Rock & AC formats with her catchy tunes and often personal songwriting ability.

In recent years she has retreated back to her gospel roots after her records began to stall on the charts but Amy is best when she sticks to what she does best---upbeat songs with a positive message.

Before parting ways with A&M, Amy released a Greatest Hits collection complete with all her hit recordings new and old so this new compilation really doesn't make sense unless it's EMI's attempt to generate a buzz around her work or worse, an attempt to cash in on her past successes.

Either way, there is nothing new here.

Let's hope Amy finds the excitement again that helped create past album gems like Heart In Motion & House Of Love with the lyrical balance of a personal favorite of mine, Lead Me On.

I won't quibble with what's here songwise....it's a pretty good set of Patsy's music. All but 2 of her Top 10 country hits are here (no "When I Get Through with You" or the pasted together duet "Have You Ever Been Lonely?" with Jim Reeves.) In all, 7 of these are top 10 hits from the country charts.

Soundwise, I'm sure it was fine at the time of release. However, since then, advances in CD technology have made it possible both to fit more songs on a disc (up to 80 minutes) and remastering improvements have made the sound quality you can achieve, even on "vintage" recordings, much better.

BOTTOM LINE:
For these reasons, I'd argue that your best choice if you want only ONE disc of Patsy's music is THE DEFININITVE PATSY CLINE (ASIN B000002X0P). But if you know you can't spend much money, the used price can't be beat.

well, i was pleading for soilwork to do something a bit more creative and less predictable after hearing FNF, and it seems they did at least try to do SOMETHING... Unfortunately, all it was, was play a bit faster and harder. This is definitely heavier than FNF was, but the way they write the tunes hasn't changed all that much. The songs, dare i say, have actually gotten more predictable... the structure is no different from your average pop tune, and because of that, there is no way i can rate this higher than 3 stars, and even that is a gift.

I listened through this album a couple times, and there didn't seem to be anything at all that made my ear perk up and my eyes widen like they did the first time i popped on The Chainheart Machine. The riffs are all 4 bars long, and they all repeat 4 times, and then they all go into a verse for 4 bars, repeated 4 times, and then they go into a chorus.... it's exactly the thing i've come to despise about pop music, and they aren't fooling me. Yes, it's done in a metal context, but these are essentially fluffy formulaic songs that go nowhere, akin to pop. Granted, Soilwork never were THAT adventurous to begin with, but they did what they did so well, that it still sounded great... they came up with great riffs and lead ideas. Now, the riffs are so "standard" and the choruses so "regular", i'm not sure really what's left to be admired about Soilwork. This is the third stroke downhill for them, even though it is a step up from FNF, and i don't think i have the time to give them another chance. Too much other, more adventurous and unique music to be heard. After all, i still have their first 3 albums which i thoroughly enjoy if i want to hear Soilwork. Sorry guys, I don't think you have it anymore.

I, like the other reviewer Diana, go back a long ways with Michael Card's music and other ministries.  This latest album is yet another breath of fresh air from Card.  The lyrics, as usual, are like packing in-depth Bible studies into single tracks.  And as with other Card albums, it grows on you the more you listen and you also gain more insight in to the Biblical truths he is expounding on in lyric.

Some interesting notes:
-Michael's daughter Maggie is featured on track 2 ("What Sort Of Song?")
-"Simeon's Song" (track 4) is an old old song, but Michael has given it a completely new, rhythmic feel and an amazing new guitar arrangement (all other songs on this album are new, by the way).
-"The Bridge" (track 6) is based on the same idea as "Recapture Me" from the 1992 album The Word--that the imagination is the bridge between the mind and the heart.  This idea puts Jesus' parables in a whole new light.

The very fact that I could go on expounding upon this latest album should be reason enough for you to make the purchase--CD, Amazon MP3, or iTunes--just get it!  It is one of his most substantial albums of late.

No, really--I love Lucinda Williams.  I've liked her earlier albums and I like her voice; it's a nice change in a music genre that often seems to idealize baby-voiced vocalists like Emmylou Harris, Nanci Griffith, and Iris DeMent (all of whom are fine singers, of course, but it's unusual to hear a female singer with Williams' deep, husky, voice).

I found this album musically monotonous.  Really monotonous.  Like, sleep-inducing.  I could chalk that up to personal taste and forgive it if more of the songs had lyrics that were interesting or meaningful beyond fairly standard pop fare.  Too many of these, as much as I hate to think it, were warmed-over rhymes and old themes with no new insight.

This is where it began, the career of Janet Jackson, she was 16 at the time of its release, and who knew that she would acheive so much in her career. While this certainly isn't her best work, and it didn't receive much attention, its still a fun album to listen to. The songs are infectuous. The album is very Jackson sounding, with songs like Say You Do, Youll Never Find (A Love Like Mine) and Young Love, and theres also some ballads here like Love And My Best Friend, and Forever Yours. Her voice isn't that strong here but its still nice, I mean this is her debut album and she didn't hit it big until Control in 1986, but this is still worth checking out.

Once again Casting Crowns releases a well timed, well produced, well sung cd. With their soft core rock style (that gets me everytime) its no wonder they sell out everywhere they go. I loved this cd. Instead of being another worship band (which is not a bad thing) Casting crowns continues to challenge 'everyday Christians' to take further steps in reaching their families, friends, and God. And to do so we need to take that first step of looking at ourselves in the mirror.
